results.title: The Living forest
results.creator_credit: Suzanne Gibbs, Christopher Parsons and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World around us”.
The New Forest stands at the crossroads. For 900 years it has remained relatively unspoiled, providing a refuge for shyer animals such as badgers, deer and foxes. But the combined pressures of thousands of visitors keen to “get back to nature” plus the harvesting of trees are threatening the forest’s very existence.

results.title: The Living filter
results.creator_credit: Hornbein-Wood Films and Pennsylvania State University
results.brief_description: Describes an experiment in which municipal waste water was used to irrigate forest and farmland, thereby increasing plant growth and purifying the water to drinking quality. The experiment also suggests the potential use of the technique in reclaiming strip-mined land.

results.title: The Living daylights (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: John Glen, Michael G. Wilson, Albert R. Broccoli and Danjaq
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Touted as a possible replacement to the outgoing original Bond - Sean Connery - Timothy Dalton gave way to Roger Moore because he thought he looked too young for the role and didn’t appear until 14 years later in “The Living daylights”. Marking a more brutal instalment than usual, the film starts with a game of paintball gone wrong then moves to Czechoslovakia where Bond is entrusted with protecting the life of defecting former KGB agent Georgi Koskov (Jeroen Krabbe) who is being targeted by a sniper. When the sniper turns out to be a beautiful blonde cellist, Bond is content to wing her and pursue her later for further information. Safely back in the UK, Koskov is kidnapped and disappears, but not before he tells British Intelligence of a plot by fellow KGB agent General Leonid Pushkin (John Rhys-Davies) to assassinate British and American agents in a bid to start a nuclear war. 007 is ordered to carry out the termination issued against Pushkin, based on evidence which he considers dubious. When the name of an American arms dealer is mentioned, the plot thickens. Notable scenes include a particularly grisly death by automatic door and tobogganing on a cello case. It was also the last Bond film to use one of Ian Fleming’s original story titles. Cast also includes Maryam D’Abo, Joe Don Baker and Art Malik.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Glen, Michael G. Wilson, Albert R. Broccoli and Danjaq

results.title: The Living city
results.creator_credit: John Barnes, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Twentieth Century Fund
results.brief_description: Surveys the need for redevelopment of American cities and the forces which have created problems in urban areas; describes obstacles which deter the elimination of blighted areas and tenements and the relief of traffic congestion. Includes scenes of St Louis in 1890, and of present-day housing and building programs in Baltimore, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh.

results.brief_description: Introduces the fundamental principles of cell biology, examining structures and biochemical processes that occur in all living cells. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: The Living camera, with Paul
results.creator_credit: Robert Drew, Time-Life Broadcast, Drew Associates, Greg Shuker, R. Leacock and D.A. Pennebaker
results.brief_description: Can a murderer become rehabilitated while he sits in death row for nine years awaiting electrocution? If he can, should his sentence be commuted to life? A young Chicago attorney answers “yes” to both questions. He then undergoes the agony and elation of a successful plea to the parole board with famed Louis Nizer at his side. Filmed with hand-held camera and sound recorder.

results.title: The Living bird
results.brief_description: The bird as a living creature. Its power of flight, structure, metabolism, senses of sight, smell and hearing. Remarkable scenes show bird courtship, nesting and the hatching of eggs of both altricial and precocious types.
